headline: 'Nduja Scrambled Eggs Recipe
description: The next time you're on brunch cooking duty, forget the sides of bacon and sausage, and stir some 'nduja into your eggs instead.
name: 'Nduja Scrambled Eggs Recipe
recipeIngredient: 1/4 cup (60ml) milk or heavy cream (optional; see note)
Thinly sliced fresh chives, for serving (optional)

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium bowl, use a fork to beat eggs with milk (if using) and salt until homogenous and no visible egg whites remain, about 30 seconds.

In a 10-inch nonstick skillet, melt butter over medium-low heat until foaming. Add egg mixture and cook, stirring frequently with a heat-resistant rubber spatula, making sure to scrape bottom and sides of skillet, until eggs begin to thicken and form small curds, 6 to 8 minutes. Continue to cook, stirring vigorously to break up large curds, until eggs are thick enough to hold their shape, 3 to 5 minutes longer.

Add 'nduja and stir vigorously until incorporated and emulsified, about 30 seconds. Remove from heat and season with pepper. Divide scrambled eggs between individual serving plates, sprinkle with chives (if using), and serve right away with toasted bread.

review.reviewBody:
Scored some ndjua from Tempesta. Peppery and sublime. Made a scaled down version and I omit adding liquids to scrambled eggs. I added the ndjua first to heat and break up then added scrambled eggs. Folded in some blended Italian cheese, plated, sprinkled with some Maldon, cracked black, and dash of parm.

Fantastic. Another winner from Sasha.

Been working with nduja recently since being turned on to it by you guys. Many thanks!

That being said I don't think i would throw in a 1/4 cup into a pan of scrambled eggs! That's excessive i think. Maybe start with a tablespoon and see where it goes. A 1/4 cup was allllmost too much for the white bean stew recipe. 

Keep it up, though. This is a terrific site.

So, I just made this for a super-quick late dinner and changed a couple of things. I rendered the 'nduja in a dry nonstick pan for a couple of minutes over medium high, breaking up the 'nduja and allowing it to cook. It releases enough lovely, chili-flavored fat that I removed the cooked 'nduja with a slotted spoon and used the fat to cook the eggs. Returned the cooked 'nduja to the eggs about two minutes before the eggs were done. Topped with chives and served with toasted baguette (what we had). Transforms scrambled eggs into more of a meal. Delicious.

I like to start with the 'ndjua in a dry pan until some of the oil melts out and it just starts to brown. Then add butter and eggs, scramble per your normal process. I find this helps everything mix together more evenly.
How exactly hot dogs are "odd" with eggs? Is this a wind-up?
